questions.q: In some parts of the world, rainstorms have become more intense over the past several decades. Is that a change in weather or climate?

a.label: weather
a.feedback: Sorry! One heavy rainstorm is a weather event—but the trend of more intense rainstorms is a sign of a changing climate.

a.label: climate
a.feedback: Correct! The trend of more intense rainstorms in certain locations is a sign of a changing climate.

questions.q: Which of these atmospheric gases traps heat as part of the greenhouse effect: methane or nitrogen?

a.label: methane
a.feedback: Correct! Carbon dioxide is perhaps the most famous greenhouse gas, but methane also traps heat in the atmosphere.

a.label: nitrogen
a.feedback: Sorry! Nitrogen makes up 80% of Earth’s atmosphere but is not a greenhouse gas.

questions.q: Without the natural greenhouse effect, Earth’s temperature would be well below freezing. Is this true or false?

a.label: true
a.feedback: Correct! Without the natural greenhouse effect, the average global temperature would be around -18˚C (0˚F).

a.label: false
a.feedback: Sorry! Without the natural greenhouse effect, the average global temperature would be around -18˚C (0˚F).

questions.q: How much carbon dioxide does the average American add to the atmosphere each year?

a.label: 16 metric tons
a.feedback: Correct! The average American produces around 16 metric tons of CO₂ annually, enough to fill 192 shipping containers.

a.label: 6 metric tons
a.feedback: Sorry! The average American produces around 16 metric tons of CO₂ annually, enough to fill 192 shipping containers.

questions.q: In the US, which activity contributes more to carbon dioxide emissions?

a.label: producing electricity & heat
a.feedback: Sorry! Transportation causes more CO₂ emissions in the US—but just barely. In 2016, 35% of US CO₂ emissions came from the generation of electricity and heat; 36% from transportation.

a.label: using transportation
a.feedback: Correct! Transportation causes more CO₂ emissions in the US—but just barely. In 2016, 35% of US CO₂ emissions came from the generation of electricity and heat; 36% from transportation.

questions.q: When you hear it’s unusually hot today, is that about the climate or weather?

a.label: climate
a.feedback: Sorry! Whether it’s hot or cold, or sunny or rainy today is a reflection of daily weather conditions—not climate.

a.label: weather
a.feedback: Correct! Whether it’s hot or cold, or sunny or rainy today is a reflection of daily weather conditions—not climate.

questions.q: The ocean affects Earth’s climate. Is this true or false?

a.label: false
a.feedback: Sorry! The ocean stores vast amounts of heat and carbon, which it exchanges with the atmosphere to impact climate.

a.label: true
a.feedback: Correct! The ocean stores vast amounts of heat and carbon, which it exchanges with the atmosphere to impact climate.
